bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 15, 1890

div1.p: Lazear describes the examination process and writes that the past seven weeks have been the most profitable of his life. He details his future travel plans.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 15, 1890
div1.p:
Since I last wrote
I have done quite a number of things.
First I will tell about my work.
I think I have told you that we
have been doing two different
courses. One for junior students or
those who have had only one winter
in Anatomy. This is the class to which
we all really belong and the course
consisted in dissections with
examinations on the work of the
week each Saturday morning.
The other course is for students who
have had two winters anatomy.
This course consisted in lectures
demonstrations and examinations
every week or two, altogether covering
the anatomy of the whole body.
So in this last course I have been
over the whole subject in the course
of the seven weeks that I have been
here.

There are two prizes given in each
of these courses. In the Junior course,
at the end of the series of examinations
there were ten of us who had missed
no questions in any of the examinations.
Norris, Nicoll, and I were among the ten
and besides there was. Knapp who
is a New Yorker and a son of one
of the professors at College of Phys. & Surg.
This afternoon we went up to be
examined to see which two of us
should get the prizes. It was an
oral examination and whenever
a man missed a question he
dropped out. Finally all dropped out
except Knapp, an Englishman, and
myself. We three then kept on for a
while and at last the professor
said that he could not decide
between us, but he would try to get
the authorities to grant three prizes
instead of two.

In the third year course the contest
is not yet decided but a New Yorker
named Leaming will probably stand
first. In this course I have only
missed one question but that will be
enough to beat me as Leaming
has not missed any. However
I am very well satisfied to get one prize.
I look on the last seven weeks
as the most profitable that I have
ever spent in my life. I feel that
I have now a very good general
idea of the whole subject of anatomy.
On last Saturday afternoon Norris and
I went down to Roslin. We visited
the famous chapel. It is indeed a
gem. We then went to Roslin Castle
and from there we walked along
the banks of the Esk to Hawthordon
Castle and from there to Lasswade
where we took the train back to
Edinburgh. The walk along the Esk
was through a glen that has been
much written about by poets.

On Sunday afternoon we walked down
to Leith which is the port of Edinburgh
and took a boat ride to the Forth
Bridge. This is the magnificent
railroad bridge over the Firth of
Forth which has just been finished
costing $15,000,000. This afternoon we
visited Holyrood Palace and saw
all the curiosities there including
the ballroom picture gallery Queen
Mary's and Damley's apartments.

The best thing about Holyrood is the
old chapel which adjoins it. It is
in ruins but its architecture is
remarkably beautiful.

I am afraid that I cannot get off
on Friday as I had expected. I will
have to stay here until Thursday when
the prizes are distributed and I am
very anxious to take a little trip
among the Lakes. I also want to
spend a day at Glasgow. I will
probably go to the lakes on Friday
getting to Glasgow that night. I will
stay there over night and the next
day and return to Edinburgh,
Saturday night and go to London on
Monday. I have not yet definitely
settled about my trip to Germany
so you had better direct letters to
London until I know more, and
I will have them forwarded.
Direct them to Paris as I said, for two
weeks for I shall certainly go there
from London but after that direct
to London.

Your letter of July 3 came on Monday morning
and I enjoyed it very much. Your
letters have come regularly two every
week and I am very glad you have
written so regularly. I would have
felt lost if one did not come on
every mail I am glad to hear that
the Lyons have consented to May's
marrying in December. You say
that you have told me why Jane
Bowman comes to Pittsburgh so
often. You have not told me.
I also received your enclosed
letter from Mrs. Bowman and
the papers both of which I enjoyed.

I am sorry to hear that Mrs. Miller is not
well. She is remarkably strong for her age
but she ought to be careful of herself.

Norris and I went to the Royal Institution
and Art Galleries this morning. There
are some good pictures, a Landseer,
a Gainsborough and three Van Dykes.
We also went to Greyfriars and after-
wards saw an operation by Dr. Duncan.
